channel.title: Windows Autopilot on MEM v ENNBEE - Battles with Modern Device Management
channel.description: Recent content in Windows Autopilot on MEM v ENNBEE - Battles with Modern Device Management
channel.copyright: Â© 2024 Nick Benton, MEM v ENNBEE

item.title: Creating Windows Autopilot Virtual Machines on macOS
item.description: With all this chat about macOS device management in Microsoft Intune, I wonder how many people are macOS users but still need to test Microsoft Intune settings on Windows devices? Well fear not, there is a way to deploy a Windows Autopilot Virtual machine on your macOS device for testing.

item.title: Keeping Windows Store Apps Updated with Microsoft Intune
item.description: Now we all love the new Windows Store, especially for deploying applications from Microsoft Intune, but we should find a way to keep these UWP applications up to date without additional license cost.

item.title: Co-Managing Windows Autopilot Hybrid Join Devices
item.description: Installing the Configuration Manager client on Hybrid Azure AD Joined Autopilot devices should be an easy process right?

item.title: Proactively Renaming Hybrid Azure AD Joined Devices
item.description: Nothing has really changed in the Hybrid Join Autopilot space when it comes to device names, and we’re still stuck with useless naming conventions for these devices; sometimes a prefix and random characters just isn’t a good enough identification method for Windows devices.

item.title: Retrofitting Windows Autopilot Group Tags
item.description: Now that we know how powerful Autopilot Group Tags can be, we should look into how we can retrofit devices with these Group Tags when the OEM or Supplier didn’t bother doing their part of the deal.

item.title: Configuring Available User Languages on Windows Devices
item.description: Have you ever wondered how to ensure that a number of languages are available for selection to end users on shared Windows 10 devices? The thought hadn’t crossed my mind, but then again, you encounter new use cases and requirements on a weekly basis. This was one of those occasions.

item.title: The Hidden Power of Windows Autopilot Group Tags
item.description: A hidden gem with Autopilot service, is the Group Tag attribute for Autopilot devices, this tag can be provided during the pre-registration by a supplier or OEM, and can be configured or updated after the device has been imported. What can we use it for in Intune?

item.title: Renaming Windows Autopilot Hybrid Joined Devices
item.description: You’ve probably hit the limitation with Windows Autopilot Hybrid Azure AD Join deployments and the device name templates being less than flexible, restricting to only a prefix and, well, that’s it.
